hobby.message: Urban exploration or just drinking underground?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I collect political literature. It's a reminder of what was lost.
neutral_answer: Restless is one word for it. Everyone’s waiting for the next directive.
People talk, but nothing new under the sun.
I pass the time reading old books. Best way to stay out of trouble.
Restless, yes. Quietly frantic. Ledger made the rounds, changed the mood.
Keeps me indoors more. I focus on restoring banned literature—old pamphlets, mostly.
Harder to find material now. People cling to what was nearly lost.
Plenty of nerves. Ledger leaks set everyone off lately.
I restore banned political texts. Tricky timing, I’ll admit.
Someone smuggled in a pre-BCI tract just last night.
There’s new interest in these forgotten words, suddenly.
Restlessness is almost audible, isn't it?
Since the Ledger came out, people crave forgotten histories.
I collect and restore banned political literature—dangerous hobby, especially now.
Last week, survivors brought me fragmented pamphlets for preservation.
Helped them reconstruct vanished texts from memory, even debated nuances of language.
Feels like old resistance is threading into the present.
Restless? We're living through a reckoning, thanks to those Ledger revelations.
I collect banned political literature—archiving and repairing pieces the system erased.
Started secretly swapping annotated pamphlets in university, before BCI locked down.
Just days ago, mural-site witnesses sought out my expertise.
I taught them authenticating marks, restoration techniques—how to spot propaganda edits.
We even compared disappearance patterns across rare editions.
For once, my hobby isn’t just personal—it's part of the city’s awakening.
Feels like our hidden histories finally have an audience.
hobby_answer: Depends who’s reading it, I suppose.
Collections have their own dangers, especially these days.
Ledger’s leak made things... complicated for certain interests.
Nothing ages faster than a banned idea.
Old texts tend to draw attention now. That’s all.
Literature usually outlasts a policy, if you keep it hidden.
Some of what I collect is suddenly in high demand, thanks to recent leaks.
Mural unrest brought collectors unwanted scrutiny.
People are quoting banned pamphlets right outside my building now.
I have to be selective, even paranoid, with loans.
Too many new faces sniffing around for histories that used to stay buried.
Yes, literature holds better—especially when policy unravels in public.
I’ve spent years restoring tracts considered illegal under BCI protocols.
Suddenly, after the Ledger’s release, victims want proof their stories aren’t erased.
So I’m fielding requests for forbidden pamphlet scans, annotations, you name it.
Feels less like collecting, more like curating resistance material these days.
Last week, police raided a known private archive. Everyone’s on edge now.
The line between hobbyist and accomplice is thinner than I’d like.
Some ideas refuse to disappear—political literature just matures in the shadows.
I memorize passages from banned manifestos. Used to be only for myself.
The Ledger shook up everything—now people want the original words, not my summaries.
Been lending out first editions after curfew. Strangers quote anti-BCI lines back to me.
Curators like us are suddenly conduits, not just historians.
Had three people last night offer to trade testimonies for pamphlet fragments.
I used to worry about loss. Now I worry about misuse.
Never thought my hobby would feel this necessary—or this exposed.
You’re right—old literature endures. I started collecting after my father vanished, under Council review.
He left me an annotated booklet from the ’22 strikes. It’s forbidden outright now.
After the mural, and the Ledger, people came knocking for context—full text, marginalia, not just rumor.
I’ve guided survivors through arguments from erased theorists. Last Tuesday, I hosted four in my kitchen.
Seeing lost histories revive—painful, exhilarating. But riskier than ever—every page can be traced now.
Deleted passages sometimes reappear in new protest slogans. That irony isn’t lost on me.
Police flagged my system for ‘associative risk’ after the raids.
My BCI fell, as you’d expect. Made me grateful for memorization.
Funny—being the custodian of unwelcome truths was always my shelter. Now it feels like the front line.
